title: Optimized protocol to derive germline stem-cell-like cells from mouse pluripotent stem cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Induction of epiblast-like cells (EpiLCs) from mESCs
Timing: 2 days for steps 1–3
This section accomplishes the induction of EpiLCs from mESCs.
Prepare fibronectin-coated wells for EpiLC induction.
Coat the wells with 610 μL/well of fibronectin solution.
Incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air for at least 1 h.
Induce EpiLCs.
Prepare ESCs (in the logarithmically growing phase) as in step 38 in the "BEFORE YOU BEGIN" section.
Note: Typically, we use thawed ESCs for EpiLC induction after two or three passages.
Aspirate the 2iLIF medium for ESCs cultured in a 12-well plate.
Add 0.5 mL/well (for a 12-well plate) of prewarmed TrypLE Express.
Incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air for 4 min.
Dissociate ESCs into single cells by pipetting them several times.
Transfer the cells into a 15 mL tube.
Add 2 mL/well (for a 12-well plate) of the prewarmed wash buffer, wash the well thoroughly, and transfer the buffer to the 15 mL tube.
Centrifuge the tube at 220 × g for 3 min to pellet the cells.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the cells by tapping.
Resuspend the ESCs in 1 mL of EpiLC induction medium.
Count the number of cells by a hemocytometer.
Aspirate the fibronectin solution from the fibronectin-coated 12-well plate prepared in step 1.
Immediately add 1 mL/well of the prewarmed EpiLC induction medium.
Transfer 1.0 × 105 cells of the ES cell suspension in EpiLC induction medium to a well of the fibronectin-coated 12-well plate.
Incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air for 24 h.
Critical: The KSR concentration (1%) of the EpiLC induction medium is critical for PGCLC induction. A KSR concentration higher than 1% results in inefficient PGCLC induction.
Change the EpiLC induction medium.

Aspirate the medium and add 1 mL of pre-warmed fresh EpiLC induction medium.
Incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air for 20 h (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Critical: During ESC-to-EpiLC induction, EpiLCs acquire the competence to differentiate into PGCLCs in a transient manner, and thus it is critical to determine the appropriate induction time for each ESC line (usually around 48 h after EpiLC induction). Start with 0.8–1 × 105 ESCs/well of a 12-well plate and determine the time point when they grow to 1 × 106 cells/well (a sub-confluent state, Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B), which is often the best time for PGCLC induction. Overgrowth of EpiLCs leads to an impaired PGCLC induction efficiency. The BVSCVR ESCs show a robust PGCLC differentiation potential at 44 h after induction into EpiLCs.
Induction of PGCLCs from EpiLCs
Timing: 4 days for step 4
This section accomplishes the induction of PGCLCs from mEpiLCs.
PGCLC induction.
Initiate PGCLC induction at 44 h after induction into EpiLCs (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Aspirate the medium and wash the wells of EpiLCs with 1 mL/well (for a 12-well plate) of PBS.
Add 0.5 mL/well (for a 12-well plate) of prewarmed TrypLE Express.
Incubate the plate for 2 min at 25°C.
Add 2 mL/well (for a 12-well plate) of prewarmed wash buffer and dissociate EpiLCs into single cells by an appropriate pipetting.
Transfer the cells into a 15 mL tube.
Centrifuge the tube at 220 × g for 3 min to pellet the cells.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the cells by tapping.
Resuspend the cells with the PGCLC induction medium so that the cell concentration becomes 4,000 cells/100 μL (4 × 104 cells/mL).

Critical: For the BVSCVR line, a concentration of 4,000 cells/100 μL leads to a good PGCLC induction efficiency. Determine the appropriate cell concentration for each line (typically, 2,000 cells/100 μL (2 × 104 cells/mL) −5,000 cells/100 μL (5 × 105 cells/mL)).
Transfer 4,000 cells/100 μL of the EpiLC suspensions into single wells of Nunclon Sphera 96-well Microplates.
Incubate the plates for ∼90–96 h at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air.
Critical: The expansion potential of PGCLCs upon PGCLC culture depends on the induction time of PGCLCs and thus it is critical to determine an appropriate PGCLC induction time for each ESC line. The BVSCVR ESC-derived PGCLCs show an appropriate expansion potential after ∼90 h of PGCLC induction [after ∼4 days of PGCLC induction: d4 PGCLCs], at which time PGCLCs show a robust BV fluorescence, but have only just initiated SC fluorescence (see below (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5])). Fully BV+ and SC+ PGCLCs show a low expansion potential.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1829-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Induction of d4 PGCLCs
(A) Bright field (left) and fluorescent (second left: Blimp1-mVenus; second right: Stella-ECFP; right: mVasa-RFP) images of EpiLC aggregates (90 h after induction) containing d4 PGCLCs observed with a fluorescence stereomicroscope. Bar, 100 μm.
(B) A flow cytometric gating strategy for sorting BV+ d4 PGCLCs. The P1 gate indicates depletion of dead cells (x-axis: FSC-A; y-axis: SSC-A) (upper left). The P2 gate is for single cell selection (x-axis: FSC-H; y-axis: FSC-W) (upper middle). The P3 gate is for single cell selection (x-axis: SSC-H; y-axis: SSC-W) (upper right). BVSC sorting is also shown (x-axis: BV; y-axis: SC) (lower left). A histogram of the P3 population. The gate for the BV+ cell sorting is indicated (lower right).
PGCLC expansion culture
Timing: 5 days for steps 5–7
This section accomplishes the expansion of PGCLCs.
Prepare culture plates with m220-5 feeders.

Coat the wells with 0.5 mL/well (for a 24-well plate) of 0.1% gelatin solution.
Incubate the plate for 30 min at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air.
Thaw the m220-5 frozen stock tube (∼4–6 × 106 cells in 500 μL/tube) quickly by incubating the tubes in the 37°C water bath.
Transfer the cells to a 15 mL tube containing more than 10 times the volume of the prewarmed wash buffer.
Centrifuge the tube at 220 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the pellet by tapping.
Resuspend the cells with serum medium so that the cell concentration becomes 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Aspirate the gelatin solution of the wells, and transfer ∼2.5–5 × 105 cells/0.5 mL/well of the m220-5 cell suspension to one well of a 24-well plate.
Critical: the density of m220-5 feeder cells is critical for PGCLC expansion. Low density of m220-5 feeder cells leads to low PGCLC expansion efficiency.
Incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air for more than 4 h until the feeder cells attach over the entire surface of the wells.
After the attachment of cells, replace the medium with 1 mL/well of the PGCLC culture medium.
Sort BV+ PGCLCs (d4 PGCLC) by fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS).
Add 5 μL of DNase I stock in 1 mL of serum medium to prepare serum medium with DNase I.
Add 5 μL of DNase I stock in 1 mL of wash buffer to prepare wash buffer with DNase I.
Collect the d4PGCLC aggregates after ∼90–96 h of PGCLC induction into a 1.5 mL tube containing 1 mL of the PBS. We collect the aggregates by using a P200 pipette under a stereomicroscope.
Centrifuge the tube at 220 × g for 1 min.

Remove the supernatant by using a P1000 pipette under a stereomicroscope to avoid accidental disposal of aggregates.
Add 0.5 mL/tube of prewarmed 0.05% trypsin-EDTA/PBS and tap the tube gently several times.
Incubate the tube in the 37°C water bath for 10 min.
Periodically, tap the tube to ensure that the aggregate is fully exposed to the 0.05% trypsin-EDTA/PBS solution.
Dissociate the aggregates into single cells by carefully and rigorously pipetting with a P200 pipette.
Add 0.5 mL (in a volume equal to that of the 0.05% trypsin-EDTA-PBS) of serum medium with DNase I and pipet the suspension several times to complete the dissociation under a stereomicroscope.
Critical: The aggregates should be dissociated into single cells as much as possible. Sticky cell masses caused by genomic DNAs leaking from dead cells should be disaggregated by DNase I treatment. Insoluble aggregates caused by genomic DNAs significantly reduce the efficiency for PGCLC sorting.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the pellet by rigorous tapping.
Resuspend the pellet in the wash buffer with DNase I so that the cell concentration becomes about 5 × 106/mL.
Transfer the cell suspension through a cell strainer with 35 μm pore size to a 5 mL tube.
Keep the tube on ice until application to FACS.
Sort the BV+ PGCLCs (d4 PGCLC) using a flow cytometer according to the manufacturer’s instructions. We use FACS Aria III (BD Bioscience).
Use a 15 mL tube containing 10 mL of wash buffer to collect the sorted cells.
Record the number of sorted cells as indicated in the “sort layout” for step 7.

Critical: To obtain a high-purity cell fraction, we select the “Purity” setting of the “Sort Precision Mode”. To maintain the viability of sorted cells, we cooled the collection tube holder by using the water bath system of the BD Temperature Control Option.
Critical: See Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B (lower right) for an appropriate gating of the BV+ PGCLCs (d4 PGCLC) fraction: perform a stringent gating for BV positivity to exclude the contamination of BV-negative cells as much as possible. We typically sort BV-positive cells with BV signal intensity higher than one-third of the BV-positive population.
PGCLC expansion culture.
Centrifuge the 15 mL tube containing d4 PGCLCs at 220 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the cells by tapping.
Resuspend d4 PGCLCs in the PGCLC culture medium so that the cell concentration becomes ∼1.0 × 104/mL (refer to step 6-r for the number of cells).
Transfer 500 μL of the d4PGCLC suspension (5 × 103 cells) into a well of the 24-well plate with m220-5 feeder cells (step 5).
Incubate the plate for 120 h at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air.
Change half the volume of the culture medium at culture days 1 and 3.
Critical: In addition to m220 feeder cells, d4 PGCLCs should also be cultured at appropriate densities. Low densities of these cells might lead to a low expansion rate of d4 PGCLCs.
Generation of reconstituted testes (rTestes)
Timing: 2 weeks for steps 8–13
This section accomplishes the generation of rTestes and their culture for differentiating PGCLCs into spermatogonium-like cells.
Sort culture day 5 BV+SC+ PGCLCs (d4c5 PGCLCs) (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A) and prepare the d4c5 PGCLCs suspension.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1829-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Purification of d4c5 PGCLCs
(A) Bright field (left) and fluorescent (second left: BV; second right: SC; right: VR) images of d4c5PGCLCs. Bar, 100 μm.

(B) A flow cytometric gating strategy for sorting BV+SC+ d4c5 PGCLCs. The Q2 gate for the BV+SC+ d4c5 PGCLCs is indicated (left). One rTestis is composed of 1 × 104 cells (BV+SC+ d4c5 cells) and 2 × 104 cells (male somatic cells of gonads) (right).
Add 5 μL of DNase I stock per 1 mL of wash buffer to prepare the wash buffer with DNase I.
Wash the wells of the 24-well plate containing the d4c5 PGCLCs with 1 mL/well of PBS.
Add 0.5 mL/well of prewarmed TryPLE Express and incubate the plate at 37°C for 4 min.
Add 1 mL/well of prewarmed wash buffer with DNase I and dissociate the cells into single cells by pipetting them several times with a P1000 pipette.
Transfer the cell suspension into a 15 mL tube and add 1 mL of wash buffer (making the total volume 2.5 mL, i.e., a 5-fold dilution of the TryPLE Express).
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the pellet by rigorous tapping.
Resuspend the cells in wash buffer with DNase I so that the cell concentration becomes ∼5 × 106/mL.
Transfer the cell suspension through a cell strainer with 35 μm pore size to a 5 mL tube.
Keep the tube on ice until application to FACS.
Sort the BV+SC+ PGCLCs (d4c5 PGCLCs) using a flow cytometer according to the manufacturer’s instructions. We use FACS Aria III (BD Bioscience) (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Use a 15 mL tube containing 10 mL of wash buffer to collect the sorted cells.
Record the number of sorted cells as indicated in the “sort layout” for step 8-p.

Critical: To obtain a high-purity cell fraction, we select the “Purity” setting of the “Sort Precision Mode”. To maintain the sorted cell viability, we cool the collection tube holder by using the water bath system of the BD Temperature Control Option.
Centrifuge the 15 mL tube with sorted cells at 220 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant, dislodge the cells by tapping, and resuspend the cells in the rTestis floating culture medium so that the cell concentration becomes ∼1.0 × 104 cells/100 μL (∼1.0 × 105 cells/mL) (refer to step 8-n for the number of cells).
Keep the tube on ice.
Prepare the embryonic testicular somatic cell suspension.
Thaw the frozen stocks of mouse embryonic testicular somatic cells (∼2.5–3 × 105 cells/tube) quickly by incubating the tubes in the 37°C water bath.
Transfer the cells into a 15 mL tube containing more than 10 times the volume of the prewarmed wash buffer.
Centrifuge the tube at 220 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend the cells in 500 μL of rTestis floating culture medium.
Count the number of cells by a hemocytometer.
Add an appropriate volume of rTestis floating culture medium so that the cell concentration becomes ∼2.0 × 104 cells/100 μL (2.0 × 105 cells/mL).
Keep the tube on ice.
Prepare floating aggregates of rTestes.
Mix an equal volume of the d4c5 PGCLCs suspension and the embryonic testicular somatic cell suspension.
Transfer 200 μL of the mixed cell suspension to each well of a low binding 96-well plate so that each rTestis consists of 1.0 × 104 d4c5 PGCLCs and 2.0 × 104 embryonic testicular somatic cells.
Incubate the plate for 48 h at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air to generate floating aggregates of rTestes.
Prepare rTestes culture plates for air–liquid interphase culture.

Add 1 mL of distilled water to the peripheral 16 wells of the 24-well plates to maintain the humidity of the culture.
Add 700 μL/well of the rTestis culture medium to the inner 8 wells of the plates.
Set a culture membrane insert (ThinCertTM) into a well with the rTestis culture medium.
Note: Culture membrane inserts should be immersed in the medium. Avoid air-bubble formation between the membrane inserts and the medium.
Note: For rTestes culture under an air–liquid interphase condition, we use ThinCertTM (24-well plates and PET membrane inserts with 1 μm pore size and 2 × 106/cm2 pore density).
Transfer rTestes onto the membrane inserts.
Transfer an rTestis cultured under a floating aggregate condition for 48 h in step 10 onto the center of a membrane insert using a glass capillary equipped with a mouth pipette (Figures 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A and 7B (left)). Place one rTestis per one membrane insert.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1829-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Generation and culture of rTestes
(A) A photomicrograph of a mouth pipette equipped with a glass capillary.
(B) Magnified images of the tips of the glass capillaries for transferring the rTestes onto the membrane inserts (left) or for aspirating extra culture fluid (right). Bar, 2 mm.
(C) Bright field (left) and fluorescent (second left: BV; second right:SC; right: VR) images of the m0 (floating d2) and the m3, m7, m10, m14 rTestis under the air–liquid interface culture. Bar, 100 μm.
Aspirate the medium carried over around the rTestis on the membrane using a thin capillary (Figures 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A and 7B (right)) by capillary reaction.
Critical: Transfer rTestes onto the membranes with as little medium carryover as possible.
Culture rTestes under an air–liquid interface condition (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]C).
Culture the rTestes at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air for 2 weeks.

Replace half the medium with fresh rTestes culture medium every 2 days.
Note: We define the starting day of rTestis culture on the membrane as membrane culture day (m0).
Critical: Examine the rTestis culture periodically to evaluate whether the rTestes are undergoing appropriate development. See (Ishikura et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]) for indexes (rTestis morphology and the timing of marker-gene expression) of the appropriate development of rTestes.
Critical: During the culture, the medium may penetrate the membranes and submerge rTestes. In such a case, place a P200 pipette against the surface of the membranes and gently absorb the culture medium on the membranes.
GSCLC (germline stem-cell-like cells) derivation
Timing: 1.5 months for steps 14–21
This section accomplishes the derivation of GSCLCs from the PGCLC-derived spermatogonium-like cells in rTestes cultured for 14 days according to the GSC derivation procedures (Kanatsu-Shinohara et al., 2003[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]) with some modification.
Prepare culture plates with MEFs for GSCLC derivation.
Coat the wells of a 96-well plate (flat-bottom) with 0.1 mL/well of 0.1% gelatin solution and incubate the plate for 30 min at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air.
Thaw the MEF frozen stock tube (1 × 106 cells/tube) quickly by incubating the tubes in the 37°C water bath.
Transfer the cells into a 15 mL tube containing more than 10 times the volume of the prewarmed wash buffer.
Centrifuge at 220 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the pellet by tapping.
Resuspend the cells with an appropriate volume of serum medium so that the cell concentration becomes ∼3.0 × 105 cells/mL.
Aspirate the gelatin solutions of the 96-well flat plate.
Transfer 100 μL of the MEF suspension to the wells (3.0 × 104 cells/well).

Incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air for more than 4 h until the MEFs attach over the entire surface of the wells.
After attachment of the MEFs, replace the medium with 100 μL/well of the GSC culture medium.
Critical: for GSCLC derivation from PGCLC-derived spermatogonium-like cells, it is critical to seed the wells with a high concentration of MEFs (e.g., ∼3.0–5.0 × 104 cells/well for a 96-well plate).
Collection of rTestes from the culture inserts.
Add 1 mL of 0.5% trypsin-EDTA per 1 mL of PBS to prepare 0.25% trypsin-EDTA-PBS.
Transfer a culture insert with an rTestis to a well of a new 24-well plate without medium.
Note: Perform this quickly to prevent the rTestes from drying out.
Add 0.3 mL/well of PBS to the wells to wash the culture insert and aspirate PBS.
Add 0.3 mL/well of prewarmed 0.25% trypsin-EDTA-PBS to the wells.
Scrape off an rTestes from a culture insert using a P1000 pipette under a stereomicroscope.
Transfer an rTestis into a 1.5 mL tube with 0.3 mL/tube of 0.25% trypsin-EDTA-PBS.
Prepare to sort the PGCLC-derived spermatogonium-like cells.
Add 5 μL of DNase I stock per 1 mL of serum medium to prepare the serum medium with DNase I.
Add 13.3 μL of 7.5% BSA Fraction V per 1 mL of PBS to prepare the antibody buffer.
Incubate the 1.5 mL tube containing an rTestis (step 15-f) in the 37°C water bath for ∼10–15 min with periodical tapping.
Dissociate the rTestis into single cells by rigorous pipetting with a P200 pipette. Perform the dissociation under a stereomicroscope for visual inspection of the degree of dissociation.
Add 0.6 mL of the serum medium with DNase I.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the pellet by tapping.

Resuspend the cells with 50 μL of antibody buffer.
Add 5 μL of anti-CD9 antibody conjugated with APC and mix the cell suspension well.
Note: To strictly distinguish the autofluorescence from the VR reporter fluorescence of the spermatogonium-like cells, we use anti-CD9 antibody conjugated with APC. MCAM (Kanatsu-Shinohara et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]) can also be used as a surface marker for spermatogonium-like cells.
Incubate the tube on ice for 20 min. Tap the tube gently every 10 min.
Add 1 mL of antibody buffer to dilute the antibody.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 200 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the pellet by rigorous tapping.
Resuspend the cells in 200 μL of antibody buffer.
Transfer the cell suspension through a cell strainer with 35 μm pore size to a 5 mL tube.
Keep the tube on ice until application to FACS.
Sort spermatogonium-like cells to establish multiclonal GSCLCs from a single rTestis (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1829-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Purification of spermatogonium-like cells
(A) A flow cytometric gating strategy for sorting CD9+VR+ cells (spermatogonium-like cells) from an m14 rTestis. The P1 gate indicates depletion of dead cells (x-axis: FSC-A; y-axis: SSC-A) (upper left). The P2 gate is for single cell selection (x-axis: FSC-H; y-axis: FSC-W) (upper middle). The P3 gate is for single cell selection (x-axis: SSC-H; y-axis: SSC-W) (upper right). An example of CD9+VR+ cells sorting is shown (x-axis: VD9-APC; y-axis: VR) (lower left). The P4 gate for the CD9+VR+ cells is indicated. P4 population (CD9+VR+) cells are reflected in FSC-A; SSC-A dimension. Note that the CD9+VR+ cell population is located to the lower right of the P1 gate.

Sort the VR+CD9-APC+ cells (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A (lower left), P4 population) (step 16) by using a fluorescence-activated cell sorter (FACS) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. We use FACS Aria III (BD Bioscience).
Collect the sorted cells into a 15 mL tube containing 10 mL of wash buffer.
Record the number of sorted cells as indicated in the “sort layout”.
Critical: To obtain a high-purity cell fraction, we select the “Purity” setting of the “Sort Precision Mode”. To maintain the viability of sorted cells, we cool the collection tube holder by using the water bath system of the BD Temperature Control Option.
Centrifuge the tube at 220 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and dislodge the pellet by rigorous tapping.
Resuspend the pellet in 100 μL of the GSC culture medium.
Transfer 100 μL of the VR+CD9-APC+ spermatogonium-like cell suspension into the well of a 96-well plate (flat-bottom) with MEFs (step 14) (200 μL/well in total).
Incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air.
Note: Typically, 200–1000 cells/rTestis can be sorted.
Sort spermatogonium-like cells to establish monoclonal GSCLCs (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).
Prepare 96-well plates (flat-bottom) with MEFs (step 14).
Sort the VR+CD9-APC+ cells (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A (lower left), P4 population) (step 16) onto a 96-well plate by using a fluorescence-activated cell sorter (FACS) equipped with an automated cell deposition unit (ACDU) having a single cell plating setting according to the manufacturer’s instructions. We use FACS Aria III (BD Biosciences).
Critical: To obtain a high-purity cell fraction, we select the “Single cell” setting of the “Sort Precision Mode”. To maintain the viability of sorted cells, we cool the collection tube holder by using the water bath system of the BD Temperature Control Option.
Aspirate the serum medium and add GSC culture medium into the wells (200 μL/well in total).

Centrifuge the 96-well plate at 100 × g for 3 min using a TOMY-CAX571 centrifuge to adhere the cells to the bottom of the wells.
Incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air.
Establish GSCLC lines (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1829-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. GSCLCs
A phase contrast image of mouse BVSCVR GSCLCs. Bar, 100 μm.
Prepare the GSC culture medium.
Change half the volume of the GSC culture medium every 2 days.
When one or a number of grape-shaped colonies are observed under an inverted microscope, passage all cells in one well of a 96-well plate to one well of a 48-well plate with MEF (see step 14).
Similarly, passage progressively from a 48-well to a 24-well to a 12-well and to a 6-well plate.
Note: From ∼1−103 spermatogonium-like cells, GSCLC colonies with a typical grape-like colony morphology (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]) are formed in ∼2–3 weeks of culture. When grown up to a 6-well plate scale, the passage number is four and the number of cells reaches a 106-cell order. We consider that GSCLC lines are established when the cells grow stably and can be passaged more than five times. Prepare several freeze stocks at an early passage (step 21).
Passage GSCLCs (as an example, we will describe a passage from a 96-well to a 48-well plate).
Prepare a 48-well plate (flat-bottom) with MEFs (see step 14).
Note: Typical numbers of MEFs/well are as follows: 2 × 104 cells/96-well, 5 × 104 cells/48-well, 1 × 105 cells/24-well, 2 × 105 cells/12-well, 5 × 105 cells/6-well plate. The number of cells required depends on the viability of MEFs. A key point is that each well should be covered with MEFs without gaps.
Prepare a 1.5 mL tube containing 500 μL/tube of the prewarmed wash buffer.

Aspirate the medium of the wells of the 96-well plate with GSCLCs.
Add 100 μL/well of prewarmed TrypLE Express, and incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air for 4 min.
Dissociate the GSCLCs into single cells by pipetting them several times and transfer the cells into a 1.5 mL tube with a P200 pipette.
Add 100 μL/well of the prewarmed wash buffer to the wells, wash the wells thoroughly, and transfer the suspension to the 1.5 mL tube.
Centrifuge at 220 × g for 5 min to pellet the cells.
Aspirate the supernatant under a stereomicroscope to avoid accidental disposal of the cell pellet.
Resuspend the cells in 250 μL/tube of GSC culture medium.
Transfer the cell suspension to the well of a 48-well plate with MEFs.
Incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air.
Prepare frozen stocks of GSCLCs.
Passage GSCLCs up to a 6-well plate as described in step 20.
Note: When ∼2.0–3.0 × 105 GSCLCs are passaged into a well of a 6-well plate, they typically become confluent (∼3.0–5.0 × 106 cells/well of a 6-well plate) after 7 days of culture. Accordingly, from one 6-well plate, ∼2.0 × 107 GSCLCs can be harvested, and ∼40 tubes (5 × 105 cells/tube) of GSCLC frozen stocks can be prepared.
Aspirate the medium, add 1 mL of prewarmed TrypLE Express/well of a 6-well plate, and incubate the plate at 37°C in 5% CO2, 95% air for 4 min.
Dissociate the cells into single cells by pipetting them several times and transfer the cells into a 50 mL tube.
Add 4 mL/well of the prewarmed wash buffer, wash the wells thoroughly, and transfer the suspension to the 50 mL tube.
Count the number of the cells using a hemocytometer.

Centrifuge the 50 mL tube at 220 × g for 3 min and aspirate the supernatant.
Add CELLBANKER I plus so that the concentration of the cell suspension becomes ∼1.0 × 106 cells/mL and transfer 500 μL to each cryotube (5.0 × 105 cells/tube).
Store at −80°C.
